title: meeting-arranged-in-bid-to-save-cockenzie-and-port-seton-gala
story: Organisers previously announced following their emergency general meetingyesterday eveningthat the gala, which celebrated its th anniversary last year,had been cancelled due to a lack of support.A statement issued on Facebook by Cockenzie and Port Seton Gala committee said:"Following on from the poor attendance at our EGM, it is with deep regret that we must inform you that the  gala is cancelled and future galas are also in jeopardy."We appreciate this will be deeply upsetting for you all to hear."We will look to organise a disco event for the gala children as a small compensation."We tried our best but we can no longer carry on with the number of committee we have."However,after an outpouring of support on Facebook, the committee has decided to review the decision to cancel the gala, although its future is still uncertain.A meeting will be held on Thursdayand all volunteers and potential committee members are encouraged to attend.The meeting takesplace at pm at Port Seton Community Centre cafe, with any queries to be emailedto cpsgala@hotmail

title: developer-looks-to-have-plans-rubber-stamped-for-another-150-houses-in-gullane
story: CALA Homes already has planning permission in principle for the site at Saltcoats Field, on the villagersquos south-eastern edge.Now they will look for the local authority to approve the design, which includes eight three-bedroom apartments and  three-bedroom detached and semi-detached homes.A further  properties are split into  four-bedroom detached villas and  five-bedroom detached villas.Registered Social Landlord People for Places will also provide  affordable properties.That will be made up of eight one-bedroom apartments and a dozen two-bedroom apartments.Ten two-bedroom semi-detached properties will also be created, alongside eight three-bedroom semi-detached homes.Tom Drysdale, chairman of the villagersquos community council, which also covers Dirleton, Aberlady, West Fenton and Drem, said: ldquoPlanning permission in principle was given some time ago.ldquoWhat they have applied for is detailed planning permission.ldquoWe have been looking at that, the community council has been looking at that, and I think we accept there is not much point nit-picking about the development ndash it is going to happen.However, Mr Drysdale felt there were details of the plans that could be improved.The main point was the lack of connectivity between the existing properties in the village and the proposed development site.Mr Drysdale said: ldquoThey are big houses, with two cars, and people are simply going to use their cars.ldquoThat was the area we have written in, making those comments, and hope the council will take on board.According to the developer, the proposals will help to meet the growing need for new family homes in the local area, with the properties appealing to a erse range of buyers.The development will also see CALA invest a further pound.m into local infrastructure, including schools, transport, sports pitches, play equipment and rail contributions.Other proposals by CALA include a footway from Gullane to West Fenton, forming part of the Drem-Gullane Core Path link.Derek Lawson, land director with CALA Homes , said: ldquoSaltcoats Field will be a logical follow-on from our current developments in Gullane.ldquoSubject to the planning process, we hope to be in position to commence development in , with homes for sale being available in .

title: labour-and-liberal-democrats-announce-haddington-by-election-candidates
story: The vice-chairman of Ormiston Community Council has been announced as Labourrsquos candidate for the seat vacated by the resignation of Conservative councillor Brian Small last month.Neal Black will represent Labour as they attempt to secure a third seat in the Haddington and Lammermuir ward.Provost John McMillan and Councillor Shamin Akhtar were elected as Labour councillors in  and will be hoping Mr Black, who works as a learner engagement officer at Edinburgh College, joins them in the ward.Tom Trotteris the other sitting councillor in the ward.Mr Black also represents Ormiston on Farsquoside Area Partnership andhas a long association with Ross High RFC, where he is currently the clubrsquos secretary.He said: ldquoIrsquom delighted that local members have put their faith in me to contest this important election.ldquoI can think of no greater honour than being able to serve the community where I was born and have lived my whole le.ldquoIrsquom looking forward to giving my all to the campaign and talking to as many people as possible over the coming weeks.ldquoMy priority will always be standing up for local interests and defending local services.The current Labour-led administration has made signicant investment in the communities that make up the Haddington and Lammermuir ward.Meanwhile, Stuart Crawford will represent the Scottish Liberal Democrats at theby-election, which takes place on May .The count takes placethe following day at Meadowmill, near Tranent, with Haddingtonrsquos Corn Exchange undergoing a major refurbishment.Mr Crawford is a writer and journalist,as well as a trustee of Haddington Garden Trust.He said: ldquoI am really looking forward to being given the chance to represent residents of the Haddington and Lammermuir ward where I live.ldquoIt is important that the concerns of local people in vital local issues such as the pressures increased housing bring on the area are put above party interests.ldquoToo often local peoplesviews are ignored in the interests of party politics.I seek to reverse this.The Scottish Conservatives announced last week that Craig Hoy would be representing them at the by-election.The SNP have not yetannounced a candidate for the by-election.

title: council-paying-20-per-cent-over-valuation-for-new-sheltered-housing-in-tranent
story: The new development in Tranent will see four one-bedroom and eight two-bedroom flats bought by the local authority for pound.million.Planning chiefs said that the decision to pay above the district valuerrsquos recommended value of pound.million was taken because they believed it was good value for money.And they argued it was hard to value the new properties correctly as there were no other homes like them in the town.The flats, being built on the site of a former dairy on Elder Street in the town centre, will be bought by the council once complete.A report on the purchase, which has been agreed by the council with the local developer, said that although they were designated as sheltered housing, no warden accommodationor common room was included on the site.It said: ldquoWhilst these properties will be restricted to specialist housing, discussions are currently being held as the preferred client group. This may result in the designation being changed from sheltered housing in the future.The report revealed that the final purchase price for the flats, which will include a lt and sprinkler system, was above the district valuerrsquos valuation of the propertyrsquos worth by some pound,.However, planning chiefs said there was evidence that the development represented value for money. The report adds: ldquoThe valuation of these flats in Tranent is dficult as there are no other similar flats for sale in the area to make a comparison with and consequently may be under-valued.The flats will be added to the councilrsquos rental stock once available.

title: hollywood-star-films-advert-in-east-lothian
story: The star of Hollywood films Pacic Rim Uprising, Kong: Skull Island, and The Great Wall was filming an advert for a Chinese water company.She was performing alongside American model, actor and writer Donny Lewis in the promotion for Ganten Water.A -strong production team headed to the venue for the shoot.Sir Francis Ogilvy, owner of Winton Castle, said: ldquoIt was a genuine pleasure to meet everyone who was part of the team filming at Winton.ldquoMy personal thanks to them all for bringing something out of the ordinary to our side of the country.

title: top-author-and-wildlife-cameraman-added-to-fringe-by-the-sea-line-up
story: The author will be discussing le and books and is one of many stars taking to the stage across the town at this yearrsquos event.The festival has also announced that award-winning Blue Planet  cameraman Doug Allan will be sharing his adventures in a talk entitled lsquoNatural Born Thrillersrsquo.They join a line-up including Eddi Reader, Fred MacAulay, Christine Bovill, Val McDermid and The Cuban Brothers.Co-director Niall Middleton said: ldquoWersquore really looking forward to seeing all the acts we have programmed so far. Performers love the opportunity to come to North Berwick and the word is out that this is definitely a cool festival in which to be involved.Niall added: ldquoWe simply could not run without our team of dedicated and passionate volunteers and we are keen to hear from anyone who may want to help us put the show on the road.Meanwhile, festival organisers say they are ldquoworking hard to confirm RB legend Alexander OrsquoNealrsquos appearance at North Berwick this year.OrsquoNeal had originally been named in the line-up but a contractual issue put his appearance in doubt.A Fringe by the Sea spokesman said: ldquoWersquove had to put ticket sales for Alexander OrsquoNeal on hold, but we are working hard to confirm him for this yearrsquos festival and wersquoll provide an update as soon as we can.For ticket details, go to www.fringebythesea

title: east-lothian-school-pupils-to-take-part-in-strike-against-climate-change
story: The NBHS Eco Committee have encouraged students to travel by public transport to attend the rally campaigning for stronger government action to combat climate change.The Edinburgh protest is one of many around the world that are happening tomorrow morning, where school children are walking out of classes to protest climate change.The protest starts at am outside the Scottish Parliament.An East Lothian Council spokesperson said: ldquoWe want to support our young people as global citizens to have their voice and to be able to express their views on important matters such as climate change."The safety and wellbeing of our young people is of paramount importance to us. We would therefore ask that any young person who wishes to attend this event first discusses it with their parent or carer before notying the headteacher of the intention to be absent from school on this date."Given that the young person will not be on school premises at this time, and therefore not the responsibility of school staff, they will be marked as having had an unauthorised absence.

title: three-hour-jumpathon-for-red-nose-day-at-musselburgh-trampoline-park
story: The team at Jump In in Newhailes Industrial Estate will need to have a real spring in their step when they don their pyjamas to take part in a national -hour Jumpathon relay with the companyrsquos seven other UK sites.Theyrsquore inviting more jumpers to join them for their three-hour session in aid of Comic Relief between pm and pm tomorrow .There will be the chance to donate on the day or those who canrsquot attend but would still like to show their support can visit justgiving fundraising jump-inGareth Trail, regional manager for Jump In, said: ldquoWe are delighted to be involved in Red Nose Day, raising money for so many special causes.ldquoWe would love to see as many people as possible down here on the day showing their support to our staff, who will be jumping for three hours non-stop.Other attractions on the day will include face-painting, a cake sale and raffle with a hamper full of Jump In goodies up for grabs.

title: cockenzie-and-port-seton-gala-saved
story: The galas organising committee had announced on Monday evening that this years gala had been cancelled due to a lack of volunteers.But an outpouring of support on social media caused an emergency meeting to be held yesterday eveningto consider the future of the gala.And following that meeting, the gala committee posted on Facebook: ldquoWe would like to give a big thank you to all who attended the EGMtonight."We are thrilled to announce that we are now in a position to go ahead with the  gala.Full steam ahead!Cockenzie and Port Seton Gala celebrated its th anniversary last year and is one of the largest galas in East Lothian.

title: tranents-redeveloped-former-co-op-building-getting-ready-to-re-open
story: The building on Winton Place is being converted into a Post Office, convenience store and coffee shop by well-known local couple George and SusanThomson.ldquoWe want to expand the business but we also want a nice place for people in the community to go and socialise, said George. ldquoWe want to draw people to the High Street.ldquoWersquove ran the Post Office in Tranent for over  years now, added Susan. ldquoWersquore really involved with the community, so this project was important to us in so many ways.As well as being postmaster, Susanco-founded the Blooming Belters and is the secretary of the townrsquos gala committee.ldquoAlthough wersquore converting a lot of it, it will still be able to host the local groups and charities that make this community so special, she said.The Thomsons worked closely with Historic Scotland to ensure that the Edwardian building retained its original charm, including putting in stained glass windows around the outside of the structure.George said: ldquoThe stained glass windows help make the building look how it would have looked a hundred years ago.ldquoHistoric Environment Scotland had also asked to have a temporary exhibition about the history of shopfronts in the country over the last  years, and there was so much interest in it that wersquove made it into a permanent display.The impressive window display covers all styles of shopfronts in Scotland throughout the century, giving information on the dferent materials used, accompanied by an archive of photos of shops dating back to the late s.ldquoThe work wersquove done with Historic Scotland is a perfect example of a public and private partnership that can maintain and renovate listed buildings, George said.The plans for the building have been in the making since  and Susanrecalled the highs and lows of taking on such project.ldquoItrsquos great finally seeing it all come together, she said. ldquoAt the start itrsquos dficult to see what it will look like and, of course, itrsquos a lot of work. Wersquore excited for it to be open and for people to get to see the finished product. We think itrsquoll be pretty special, especially in the summer when we get the chairs outside and all the flowers are in bloom.The opening in April will mark the end of phase one for the Thomsons.Phase two will involve creating a soft play area and flats above the shop, as well as a community hall.The work on phase two will begin in August, with hopes that the whole project will be completed by .

title: Glasgow  Gateway to Scotland  The best golfing experiences within 90 minutes of the city centre
story: None more so than the golfers among them. Blessed with an abundance of courses ndash including two within three miles of the city centre ndash to suit every skill level and bank balance, the city and its environs is a golf-loverrsquos paradise.Those looking to challenge themselves with a championship-level course are also spoiled for choice, with some of the worldrsquos great and most historic golfing venues only a short drive away.Yoursquoll need a respectable handicap to play on many of these hallowed fairways and some offer only limited access to non-members. All Scotlandrsquos most famous courses are in wonderful locations, however, and some are attached to the sort of luxurious destination hotels worth visiting in their own right.With this in mind, wersquove set ourselves a spring sporting challenge: the best golfing experiences within  minutes of Glasgow city centre.GlasgowLetrsquos start with the impressive list of top-notch, visitor-friendly courses in and around the city itself. Two of them - Haggs Castle and Pollok - are a mere  minutesrsquo drive from the city centre. Meanwhile, in nearby leafy East Refrewshire, Cathcart Castle and Braid - designed by Scots five-time Open winner James Braid - both offer panoramic views of the city and beyond. Westerwood, in Cumbernauld, was designed by the late, great Seve Ballesteros and overlooks the Campsie and Kilsyth hills, while wildle fans always enjoy keeping an eye out for deer and buzzards during a round at Cawdor, in Bishopbriggs.PrestwickVenue for the first ever Open Championship in  ndash and another  after that - this beautul Ayrshire links course, originally laid out as -holes by ldquoOld Tom Morris, the father of modern golf, offers a tough challenge and great views across to Arran. The most testing elements include the infamous Cardinal bunker at the third hole and the Himalayas on the fth. Prestwick itself, meanwhile, has much to offer, including a lovely beach. And itrsquos all just -minutes from Glasgow.Royal TroonFounded in  and laid out by the greenkeeper at neighbouring Preswick, the Old Course at Royal Troon remains one of the most demanding courses in Scotland. Yoursquoll need to be a confident shot-maker to contend with the wind ndash not to mention the gorse ndash on these linksand access is limited for non-members. For those not playing, charming and historic Troonoffers an array of family-friendly attractions including two beaches and plenty of great restaurants.TurnberryJust round the coast from Troon, some  minutes from Glasgow, is Trump Turnberry, the golf resort owned by US President Donald Trump which boasts one of the most scenic courses of them all, and a luxurious Edwardian hotel and spa. Overlooking craggy Ailsa Craig with views to Arran and the Mull of Kintyre, the Ailsa coursehas been challenging amateurs and professionals alike since . The King Robert the Bruce Course was added in , bringing a whole new dimension to the golfing experience at Turnberry.Ear of MarLocated in  acres of ancient parkland on the banks of the River Clyde, with excellent views of the Erskine Bridge, this stunning course is just half an hour from Glasgow and  minutes from the cityrsquos airport. Once home to the Earl of Mar, the grand mansion which forms part of the resort was built in  and is now residence of choice for celebrities such as Beyonce, Brad Pitt and Kylie Minogue when they visit Glasgow. Whether itrsquos a round of golf, relaxing spa or delicious afternoon tea yoursquore after ndash or indeed all three ndash this place has it all.Carrick on Loch LomondDescribed as having ldquothe most beautul water hazard in the world in the shape of Loch Lomond, this -year-old course just  minutes from Glasgow is an experience from start to finish and has played host to championships including the Ladies Scottish Open, PGA Cup and Europro Tour. A fire devastated part of Cameron House, the resort hotel, in December  but a full restoration is under way and expected to be completed in early . The spa, restaurants and lodges remain open.GleneaglesTaking pride of place in the Perthshire countryside, only an hour from Glasgow, the iconic Gleneagles Hotel has been welcoming guests since . Itrsquos also home to three championship courses, including the Kingrsquos and Queenrsquos, which both celebrate their centenaries this year. The third course, the PGA Centenary, hosted the Ryder Cup in , the scene of a famous win for Europe. In September, Europersquos women golfers will be hoping for a similar result when the Solheim Cup is contested there.MuirfieldOne of the oldest golf clubs in the world - which also goes by the name of The Honourable Company of Edinburgh Golfers- started out in Leith in . It later moved to Musselburgh before settling at its current home in Gullane, East Lothian, in , where it was laid out by Old Tom Morris. Host of The Open  times ndash Jack Nicklaus won three here ndash this exclusivelinks course overlooks the Firth of Forth and is just  minutes from Glasgow. A bucket-list destination for golf aficionados, Gullane is home to another prestigious golf club, founded in , with another three courses. The townrsquos stunning coastal location and abundance of excellent hotels, pubs and restaurants, meanwhile, ensure year-round popularity with those who ndash whisper it ndash donrsquot play golf.St AndrewsRequiring little in terms of an introduction, the home of golf ndash the game has been played on the links here since the early th century - is always a joy to visit. The ancient Fe town is simply steeped in golfing history, myth and legend and hosts seven courses, the headquarters of the sportrsquos governing body and an entertaining museum, not to mention the most famous bridge in sport. The Open s to its Old Course home roughly every five years. Not surprisingly, itrsquos pretty tough to get a game on the hallowed links,but being a public course over common land means anyone can have their picture taken on the aforementioned Swilken Bridge. The townrsquos six other excellent courses -the Balgove, Eden, Jubilee, New, Castle and Strathtyrum - offer an array of opportunities for players of all levels. Even the putting course here, known locally as the Himalayas, is iconic. As are some of the townrsquos hotels, which include the Old Course and the Rusacks.MusselburghDocumentation shows that people have been playing golf in this Lothian town since at least , no doubt enjoying the same views over the Firth of Forth. The shoreline links here played a critical role in the development of The Open and provided its first ever champion, Willie Park Snr. These days there are an array of prestigious clubs and courses ndash including Musselburgh Links, which claims to be the oldest course in the world still in play - each offering a dferent challenge. The town,  minutes from Glasgow, is also famous for its racecourse and has some excellent restaurants.BruntsfieldFounded in , this prestigious Edinburgh course ndash said to be the fourth oldest in the world - recently underwent a major redevelopment. The inland location ensures a dferent type of challenge to the east coast links courses, though what it will always have in common with them are the excellent views across the Firth of Forth.

title: top-snp-figures-launch-formal-complaint-against-bbc
story: SNP depute leader and Westminster leader Ian Blackford raised "two formal complaints" against the broadcaster in a joint letter, according to an exclusive report in The National.The senior figures in the party accused the BBC of downplaying the role the SNP has at Westminster because they represent Scotland. They also say that the broadcaster under-represents them on flagship BBC shows.It comes after the BBC cut away from the SNPs Ian Blackford twice as he was speaking after statements from Theresa MayandJeremy Corbyn on the main BBC channels. They also cut away from theCommonsjust as Blackford was standing up to give his opening remarks in the original debate over Mayrsquos deal on Tuesday.BBC One, which showed both Theresa Mayrsquos statements and Jeremy Corbynrsquos responses, would likely have had an average audience share of around .%. Ian Blackfordrsquos speech was broadcast on the BBC Parliament channel, which has an audience share of just .%.In a letter to the BBC the senior SNP figures wrote: "So far this week we have seen three consistent and deliberate editorial decisions taken to cut off parliamentary coverage on News Specials from the moment Ian Blackford spoke in theHouse of Commons. The consequence of these editorial decisions is to relegate the third party at Westminster":Ian Blackford: Calls for permission to hold Indyref must be accepted by UK GovernmentThe pair also say the BBC is ldquoin breach of its mission and responsibility to serve licence fee payers across every UK country, erasing the SNP from its coverage by ldquoconsistent and deliberate editorial decisions.The letter continues: ldquoThis pattern of behaviour follows recent research and media reports which revealed that Newsnight did not feature a single SNP politician in the entirety of February.ldquoAnd in January, the revelation that Politics Live had just two SNP guest slots out of a total of  guest slots.:BBC Question Time faces fresh row over claims it edited SNP retort to former UKIP candidateldquoWe would like to understand how the BBC believe they are serving the audience in Scotland in each of these examples.ldquoTherefore, regarding our first complaint, it is our contention that BBC coverage of Westminster parliamentary business is suggestive of a deliberate policy of BBC editors and managers to demote the status of the third party at Westminster because that party represents only Scotland.ldquoRegarding our second complaint, we contend that the under-representation of the SNP from flagship programmes such as Politics Live and Newsnight provide evidence of a continuing failure by the BBC ndash set out over a decade ago in the highly critical King Report ndash to serve all audiences in the UK in equal measures."A BBC spokesperson confirmed to us: ldquoWe have received the letter and will respond directly in due course.You can read the full story in The National

title: unspun-the-political-diary
story: MUSICAL goings-on at Holyrood too, where MSPs are forming a band. The Commons already has the popular MP featuring the SNPrsquos Pete Wishart. Holyroods answer has Labourrsquos Pauline McNeill on vocals, Tory Brian Whittle and Labourrsquos Daniel Johnson on guitars, and possibly Nat Tom Arthur on keyboards. All they need is a drummer and a name. Rumours that Murdo Fraser wants to plays the flute are wholly untrue.BUT does Mr Whittle have what it takes to rock out  On Tuesday, he was so appalled by Westminster shenanigans over Brexit, he left Holyrood to go home and strum wistfully for hours rather than tune in for the vote. Aw, lambkin.HEROIC abstainer David Mundell has been getting it raw after sitting out Wednesdayrsquos crunch vote on no-deal. Just last month the Scottish Secretary previously said no-deal would cause extreme harm to the Union, vowing: ldquoI will do whatever I deem necessary to prevent a no-deal Brexit! Translation: up to and including nothing.SO farewell then, David Stocks, leader of the chaotic SNP opposition on North Lanarkshire Council, who gives up the post on Monday. At least he wonrsquot be at a loose end, having friends in many places. Like the Orange Order, for instance. In , he enjoyed dinner at the lsquoOrange Oscarsrsquo, when the ultra-Unionist No campaigners gave gongs to outstanding lodges. ldquoWe live in a culturally erse area, the Nat councillor shrugged. Ah, Lanarkshire.BUT itrsquos welcome back to Dan McCroskrie, the improbable Tory candidate in the Western Isles in , who is now standing for Edinburgh Council in the Leith Walk by-election. Dan famously used a picture of voter-free St Kilda on his last election leaflet, then spent much of the campaign working at Holyrood. With an absentee candidate, the Tory vote jumped  per cent.AT least Mr McCroskrie is a Leith resident, and so unlikely to use another snap of an island abandoned in  on his bumf this time. It sounds like the locals know him too. At this weekrsquos hustings he was instantly booed. However our mole reports he won over the crowd with a joke about snooty Morningside - where Tories actually get elected.STRANGEST debate of the week was Wednesdayrsquos Holyrood blether about space. Nat Kenny Gibson recalled going to the pub aged  to watch Star Trek ldquoover a Coca-Cola while his mum watched Coronation Street. That was before video recorders he explained to deputy PO Christine Grahame, ldquoalthough I know for you, it was the invention of the talkies that changed your world. She got her own back by cutting him short at the end. ldquoConclude! I am sorry, butyou make an ageist comment... you cannot expect me to be sympathetic.

title: highland-cinema-gets-go-ahead-and-building-is-due-to-start-within-weeks
story: West Highland businessman Angus MacDonald said the cinema and cafe bar in the centre of the town is scheduled for completion in  months.Mr MacDonald does not plan to make money from the venture, but instead give something back to the community in which his family has lived for centuries.He said: ldquoI was very keen on getting the right site, it was the old town hall until  when it burned down."It was later a shop owned by DV.ldquoI bought thatin October last year and appointed Dualchas the architects and Galbraiths as the project manager.ldquoWe came up with a building designed around a traditional highland building, which was design-led by me.ldquoI think it is a very warm, attractive traditional building.":Paper sculpture to aid Old Royal High School campaign, new cinema plan, Buke of Howlat rebornMr MacDonald set up three open days which attracted  people. The construction firm from Ayr, b, hasprepared the site.He added: ldquoWe have achieved planning permission, so in record time through to planning.ldquoWe are now waiting on a building warrant and I suspect we will start building in a month.ldquoThe plan is to open in time for thesix day motorbike trials next May, so  months from now.There will be one -seater screen and an -seater screen, and an -seat cafe bar, above, and a terrace overlooking the square.With no other funders, it is expected to cost Mr MacDonald ldquoseveral million pounds.He said: ldquoI will be the owner but I donrsquot expect to make a penny infrom it.ldquoItrsquos got to cover its costs when itrsquos up and running anditrsquos got to cover the depreciation and all that and wersquoll have to buy new stuff every  years.":pound.m payday for investors in waste recycling firmHe added:ldquoBasically Irsquom doing it for the town. My family have lived there for , years.ldquoI will pay what it takes to get a fantastic building."Hersquos no film buff he says but ldquoenjoys going to a good film.ldquoIt is the people and the economy of the West Highlands that interest me.He added: ldquoWe have , tourists in Fort William and therersquos not a lot for them to do on a wet evening.Mr MacDonald, above, is an entrepreneur and philanthropist and has sold businesses he builtup for more than pound million, this week selling his Specialist Waste Recycling firm to Bfa for over poundm in a deal fromwhich he earned about poundm.He has set up a book shop in the town and is responsible for founding the CaledonianChallenge event which has raised more than poundm for good causes.Highland Council planning documents confirm full planning permission has beengranted for the project subject to minor conditions including providing exterior finish details and works provision information.

title: dup-holding-significant-talks-with-government-over-brexit
story: A source said the Unionist party was engaging in "ongoing and signicant discussions with Government" on Friday.Support from the DUP could lead to Mrs Mays deal being approved by the Commons next week, after it was defeated for the second time on Tuesday.It comes as European leaders consider whether to agree to UK calls for Britains departure to be delayed.MPs backed a push-back Brexit beyond the scheduled date of March  in dramatic parliamentary scenes which saw a majority of the Conservative party in the opposite lobby from the Prime Minister.:Ian McConnell: No-deal Brexit would be awful but this particular Toryrsquos warning sticks in crawBut any delay will require the agreement of the other  European Union members, with talks about any conditions for an extension set to begin before leaders gather at a summit next week.European Council president Donald Tusk met Dutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte in The Hague on Friday before talks with the blocs key power brokers Angela Merkel and Emmanuel Macron on Monday.Following the talks, Mr Rutte said the current Withdrawal Agreement is the "only deal on the table".On Tuesday, Mr Tusk will travel to Dublin to meet Taoiseach Leo Varadkar before the summit in Brussels on Thursday.Mr Tusk said: "I will appeal to the EU to be open to a long extensionthe UK finds it necessary to rethink its Brexit strategy and build consensus around it."But European Parliament Brexit co-ordinator Guy Verhofstadt questioned why the leaders of the  should grant an extensionMrs May was "not ready for a cross-party approach to break the current deadlock" in the Commons.The Prime Minister is set to bring her Brexit deal back to the Commons for a third meaningful vote next week, and Attorney General Geoffrey Cox has sought to provide further legal assurances about the Irish backstop.But Mrs Mays hopes of persuading Eurosceptics and the DUP to back the deal were dealt a blow after the "Star Chamber" of Brexiteer lawyers rejected Mr Coxs latest assessment.The group of lawyers, led by veteran Tory Sir Bill Cash, said a suggestion that the UK could use the Vienna Convention - the international agreement that lays down the rules about treaties - to unilaterally pull out of the backstop was "badly misconceived".:Cabinet splits as MPs mandate Theresa May to ask Brussels for Brexit delayThe  of lawyers, which signicantly also includes DUP deputy leader Nigel Dodds, rejected the supplementary legal advice from Mr Cox.The Attorney Generals advice hinges on Article  of the Vienna Convention, which says thatthere has been "a fundamental change of circumstances" following the conclusion of a treaty "which was not foreseen by the parties", then the countries involved would be allowed to withdraw from it.Mr Cox said: "It is in my view clear and undoubted in those exceptional circumstances that international law provides thewith the right to terminate the Withdrawal Agreement."But the Brexit-backing lawyers said "given the high burden that a state must meet to use it, and given the extreme reluctance of international courts and tribunals to accept it", the Vienna Convention route "supplies no assurance whatsoever that the UK could terminate the Withdrawal Agreement in a lawful manner".

title: herald-diary-horses-for-courses
story: WHETHER you bet or not, you have to admire the sheer beauty of the top class horses running at Cheltenham this week. Weve had a few horsey stories over the years in The Diary including the Glasgow chap who announced in the pub that he had been for a job interview to work at a blacksmith. He told his pals: "They askedId ever shoed a horse. I told them, No, but I once gave a donkey a hard shove."Well plaidA READER once told us he was in a Paisley dress-hire shop behind a family where the father, with a tattoo of King William on a horse on his arm, declared: "Wur here fur a fittin o oor kilts." The assistant asked which tartan they required, and he replied: "Rangers tartan." Our reader admired the nerve of the assistant who then askedit was for a wedding or a First Holy Communion.What a puddingSadly many Glaswegians have only been up close to a horse when mounted police are controlling crowds at football games. The classic tale was of a match at Hampden when a drunken fan munching a black pudding supper got fed up being dunted by a police horse while he queued up and threw the rest of his supper at the back of the head of the mounted officer. A reader who witnessed this told us: "He cantered over, stretched down and grabbed the guy by the collar, who screamed, It wisnae me. Shows yer teeth demanded the cop. The ned offered up a hideous smile and the mountie roared Yer teeth are a puddin. He got the pokey.Live streamingAND a reader told us of his brother in the mounted branch who was once astride his horse at Ibrox, chivvying the turnstile queue into a semblance of order when he sensed his mare beneath him settle down for a pee. Said our reader: "Immediately as said emission hit the tarmac, a Rangers fan opined, Aw, typical ndash nae cups in the machinersquo."Neigh chancePOLICE Scotland once took to social media to ask the public to vote on the name for a new police horse, with the choice being from four Scottish place names ndash Melrose, Clarkston, Glencoe or Tiree. We liked the thinking process of one member of the public who replied to Police Scotland: "Not Melrose, because they always beat us at Sevens. Not Glencoe because of the Campbells. And not Clarkston because I canna stand the bloke and all that Top Gear rubbish. So its got to be Tiree.Horsing aboutWE once recalled actress Judy Denchs big screen breakthrough playing Queen Victoria in the Scottish-based film Mrs Brown. John Millers biography of Judi said one shot in Scotland took over  takes. Explained director John Madden: "The process of getting Judi off the horse with the voluminous skirts took care of about  takes, horse-farts took care of another five, one horse bit another, then it pushed Judi out of shot. We thought we had it perfect until Judi walked away and her costume caught on Billy Connollys radio mike.SteamingWE always liked author Allan Morrison discussing his book Last Tram Tae Auchenshuggle who explained that Glasgows original trams were pulled by horses. There was no timetable, he said, so Glaswegians instead knew thatthe manure was hot then they had just missed a tram, andthe manure was cold then a tram was due.Bet on itRETIRED lawyer Ross Harper once told the tale of his former boss Jimmy Martin being a car park attendant at a racecourse in his youth. Recounted Ross: "When people parked, he would give them a tip. He would pick a race in which there were six or more runners, and he would sidle up and whisper the name of the horse and say, Back it. Its going to win. He gave the next car owner another horse until he had tipped them all to win, making sure he remembered which car he had tipped so he could identy the winner when he came to his car.Bottoms upA READER once claimed that he was in a pub on Skye where the barmaid had a horses head tattooed on her chest, which was just visible above her top. One toper who had drank too much thought it would be funny to ask the barmaidhe could see "the horses arse." She rooted in her handbag and handed him a mirror.

title: kevin-mckenna-westminsters-political-freaks-and-curiosities-are-independences-best-recruiting-sergeants
story: The prospect then of a long stretch between the first and second referendums was a distressing one for many independence campaigners, especially I think among those who perhaps had never been involved in political campaigning before. Many new SNP supporters I talked to in the course of the campaign and afterwards had described their support for independence in messianic terms. Their conversion had been Damascene and they had begun the task of evangelising work colleagues, and family members. The struggle for Scotlandrsquos soul was fought in book-clubs, walking groups and pubs. My own dear -year-old mum, an avowed Unionist, was persuaded away from her perfidious beliefs by my two daughters who felt that her conversion was a sacred cause. She still has the Yes stickers in her window and asks me every week when the next referendum will be.Having gone through these le-altering, almost religious encounters, itrsquos entirely understandable and predictable why you would want to repeat them as soon as you could. It seemed good to be alive then ndash defeat or no defeat.Here we are though five years later and elections and referendums have come and gone at a bewildering rate and, for the first time in UK political history, a signicant portion of the population now knows what those four people who bustle through the isions at Westminster do. Mr Speaker, John Bercow is so popular hersquoll soon be hosting game shows and the BBC is already wondering how they are going to replace Andrew Neil. In American politics every day is a pantomime as the delinquent in the White House comes more and more to resemble the Manchurian Candidate. In Scotland the numbers for independence remain stubbornly defiant and other surveys indicating that a clear majority of Scots would prefer independence than exiting the EU with no deal.At next monthrsquos SNP Spring conference Nicola Sturgeon and her ministers will encounter squallsthey attempt foolishly to silence the increasingly siren calls to strike early for a second referendum. There are several sources for such optimism. As well as the numbers for independence averaging about %recent major oil discoveries have settled any fears that these reserves will have an advantageous impact on our post-independence economy. Independence supporters are fond of saying Scotland is the only country in the world which discovered oil and became poorer.Itrsquos also the only country in the world with an entire class of media and political commentators who say that oil is nothing to write home about and that itrsquos actually a burden. Happily though, the BBC, after several years, have stopped using the annual GERS numbers as a propaganda tool for the Union and started introducing some long overdue nuance to this hazy snapshot of our economy which fails to factor in, ahem ... independence and its dferent spending choices and priorities.The case for striking out early for a referendum is further buttressed by the serial and endemic incompetence of the Labour Party in Scotland. Surely, they will begin to make a recovery soon. They wonrsquot though not when they always seem to choose the janitor to run the school.And then there is Brexit, the great gt that many nationalists believe just keeps giving. Highlights from this weekrsquos Westminster convulsions should be gathered up by the SNPrsquos social media specialists and retained for use across all s when the time comes. Two very clear patterns emerged this week and neither of them is pretty. Itrsquos clear that Theresa May is becoming increasingly detached from reality and, I fear, to the detriment of her physical health and perhaps more. Her party has been given over to the whims of its howling whim and other night-time creatures.Each time her ministers face the microphone you find yourself trying to decipherthis is a serious comment about breaking the Brexit logjam or an early attempt at a leadership bid. Meanwhile, the Scottish voters who opted to remain in the EU are reminded every night that their fate is in the hands of a gang of political flat-earthers from Ulster. At one point Andrew Neil, while interviewing Nigel Farage in Brussels, seemed to be suggesting to him that he might want to speak to his far-right compadre, Matteo Salvini, the deputy Prime Minister of Italy. If Italy vetoed Britainrsquos Brexit extension plans then a no-deal scenario could present itself. I swear I could hear chops being licked.The other pattern is an old and continuing one: the contempt of Westminster for anything remotely to do with Scotland. Jeremy Corbyn dismissed any talk about Scotland being dragged out of Europe against its will and inevitable calls in the face of this for a second referendum as ldquoan irrelevance. The BBC now routinely refuses to permit coverage of SNP responses following important Commons votes on Brexit. Throughout the entire Brexit process, Mrs May and her ministers have treated the Scottish Government with disdain and ignored them at every opportunity, even when it has suggested routes that might help her. One observer told me that attempting to discuss anything with the UK Prime Minister is like sitting at traffic lights that will always be fixed at red.Letrsquos not be impatient Scotland can afford to wait a little while longer for a second referendum. This cast of political freaks and curiosities will remain with us for a while yet and, as this week has shown, they will think nothing of bring the UK to its kneesit suits their narrow agendas. That will be the time to strike.

title: nicola-sturgeon-signals-indyref2-push-before-2021
story: The First Minister told a foreign newspaper not to forget she was ldquoelected on a very clear mandate to have another referendumScotland was dragged out the EU against its will.Askedher government might wait until after  before pressing the UK to grant another vote, she replied: ldquoI wouldnrsquot say that at all.She said she was ldquoas convinced as it is possible to be that,Scotland is given the opportunity to choose again, it will choose independence.Her SNP deputy Keith Brown also said last night that this weekrsquos chaos at Westminster over Brexit may prove the point at which momentum for independence became ldquounstoppable.He said: ldquoThe last few days have proved beyond question that Westminster isnrsquot working for Scotland - the complete meltdown over Brexit has shown that clearer than ever. The UK Parliament is an unstable, undemocratic institution foisting an unwanted Brexit on Scotland.ldquoThe whole Westminster system is broken. Itrsquos time Scotland took our own decisions.The First Minister has repeatedly delayed her long-awaited update on a referendum because of Brexit uncertainty, promising an announcement "in a few weeks" for several months.Ms Sturgeon says she has a ldquotriple lock mandate for a referendum based on SNP wins in the last Holyrood and general elections, and a  vote by MSPs.Her apparent reluctance to use it since SNP reversals at the last election has frustrated parts of the Yes movement, including some of her own MPs.Her mandate comment was made in an unreported interview with Canadarsquos National Post last month in Toronto, a meeting the SNP Government revealed this week after a freedom of information request.Ms Sturgeon was asked where her government would wait until after the  ldquobefore pressing the British Parliament to grant another referendum.She replied: ldquoI wouldnrsquot say that at all. By definition, I havenrsquot come to a view on timing, so by definition I canrsquot really answer. But donrsquot forget the government I lead was elected on a very clear mandate to have another independence referendum in the circumstances that Scotland was to be taken out of the EU against our will. So I wouldnrsquot assume that it will be necessarily be after the next Scottish election.Although the UK government has said it would reject a referendum request, Ms Sturgeon could use a refusal to whip up SNP votes at the  poll.Pamela Nash, chief executive of Scotland in Union, said: ldquoThe majority of voters in Scotland donrsquot want a isive second independence referendum for at least ten years.ldquoIt would be an act of extreme recklessness to hold an unwanted and unnecessary second independence referendum. Every single opinion poll for over a year has shown that the people of Scotland know we are stronger together.Scottish LibDem constitutional affairs spokesperson Wendy Chamberlain said: ldquoThe First Minister seems to have missed the fact that people are sick of constitutional upheaval.ldquoThe SNP have clearly learnt nothing from the chaos of Brexit because theyrsquore still as intent as ever on replicating that chaos on an even greater scale.Recent polls have suggested most Scots would prefer independence over any form of Brexit, but also that a majority oppose a referendum within  years.The SNP is due to discuss its economic and currency plans for an independent Scotland at its conference next month.

title: students-campaign-worldwide-for-action-on-climate-change

I want you to feel the fear I feel every day."Yesterday, she told a rally in Stockholm that the world faces an "existential crisis, the biggest crisis humanity ever has faced, and still it has been ignored for decades".Colin Mearns NewsquestSince her campaign went viral on social media, the weekly protests have snowballed to such an extent that yesterday, pupils in nearly  countries walked out of classes to protest.In Britain alone, organisers estimate , people took part in events in  British towns and cities, including London, Brighton, Leeds, Manchester, Cambridge and Birmingham, Edinburgh and Glasgow.In Scotland, walkouts also took place in towns and cities including East Kilbride, Coatbridge, Stirling, Inverkeithing, Peebles, Fort William, Forres, St Andrews, Inverness, Ullapool, South Uist, Aberdeen, Aberdour, Kirkwall and Eigg.A number of Scottish councils said pupils would not face punishmentthey took part in the protests with parental permission.Read more:Councils urged not to punish pupils for climate strikeBut Geoff Barton, general secretary of the Association of School and College Leaders , said missing school to protest over climate change should not be condoned.Mr Barton labelled the protests "fruitless"and said children should be learning in school about why climate change matters and how political processes work.Speaking at ASCLrsquos annual conference in Birmingham, he said it would be reasonable to expect students to make up any missed work during lunchtime detentions.Education Secretary Damian Hinds said that while it was great that pupils were taking an interest in an issue that was so important in the UK, and around the world, they ldquoshould be at school.However, politicians including Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn and Environment Secretary Michael Gove offered support to young climate strikers - who are also backed by scientists, academics and campaigners.Young people gathered in Parliament Square, London, chanting, ldquoThis is what democracy looks like.Read more:Scottish schoolboy hits out at EU over global warmingAnna Taylor, , from north London - co-founder of the UK Student Climate Network, said the Government was failing to recognise the severity of the crisis.ldquoTheyrsquore failing to make environmental reform and environmental policy a priority, they focusing on economic policy and Brexit and failing to address the climate crisis facing us.In Glasgow, Marianne Mylchreest, , a Glasgow University student who joined the protest in George Square, said: ldquoWersquore out here saying that therersquos not enough being done so wersquore trying to get people to actually make a dference. ldquoItrsquos incredible - schools are coming out, unis are coming out, people that have kids are coming out, therersquos dogs here, itrsquos just great.Six-year-old Anna Arbuckle said she joined the George Square demonstrators ldquoto stop the ice from melting.Scientists have warned for decades that current levels of greenhouse gas emissions are unsustainable, so far with little effect.Read more:Pacic islanders plea to Scottish climate strike pupils: Help save our paradiseIn December, naturalist Sir David Attenborough made his feelings clear, saying climate change is humanityrsquos greatest threat in thousands of years.Speaking at the opening ceremony of United Nations-sponsored climate talks in Katowice, Poland, he said: ldquoRight now, we are facing a man-made disaster of global scale. Our greatest threat in thousands of years. Climate change. ldquoIf we donrsquot take action, the collapse of our civilisations and the extinction of much of the natural world is on the horizon.Colin Mearns NewsquestYesterdayrsquos strikes come in the wake of a UN report last year which warned limiting global temperature rises to .C above pre-industrial levels, beyond which climate impacts become increasingly severe, requires unprecedented action.Now a new report released by the United Nations warns that even emissions cuts outlined in the Paris Agreement wonrsquot be enough to prevent a rise in Arctic temperatures set to raise sea levels across the globe.According to the report, eventhe world were to meet these benchmarks, temperatures in the Arctic would continue to rise by another - degrees Celsius by .ldquoWhat happens in the Arctic does not stay in the Arctic,rsquo said Joyce Msuya, UN Environmentrsquos Acting Executive Director. ldquoWe have the science now more urgent climate action is needed to steer away from tipping points that could be even worse for our planet than we first thought.

title: more-than-230000-applications-for-irish-passports-received-in-three-months
story: Simon Coveney said that more than , applications have been received to date this year.The Irish Foreign minister said the figures represent a % increase on the same period last year.It comes after proved to be a record year with the highest numberof Irish passports ever issued.Mr Coveneyrsquos department saidover % of the  applications came from the island of Ireland.It also revealed it is expecting a further spike this weekend.During St Patrickrsquos weekend in , more thanver , people applied for an Irish passport online ndash and based on current trends, officials are expecting that number double this year.The figures come on the final countdown to the date the United Kingdom is due to leave the European Union.Last month, the passport ision of the Irish embassy in London warned that it is ldquostretched and working under pressure, and that staffing levels ldquoare not sufficient to meet the rising number of applications ahead of Brexit.Irish comedian Chris OrsquoDowd predicted in February that scores of Britons will be looking for Irish passports after March .However, the Irish Department of Foreign Affairs put the spike in applications down to an increase in travelling and a tendency towards early renewal.Mr Coveney said extra resources have been allocated to the passport service.ldquoGiven the demand we are experiencing signicant extra resources have been given to the passport service including hundreds of extra staff for processing and customer service, he said.

title: campaigners-call-for-alternative-coping-strategies-for-poorer-smokers
story: Research by the Poverty Alliance and Action on Smoking and HealthScotland found people in poverty are more likely to smoke because they are at greater risk of stress and less likely to have access to alternative coping mechanisms.Ash Scotland chief executive Sheila Duffy said: ldquoWe know only too well the harm caused by smoking, and that most people who smoke say that they want to stop.ldquoBut we need to listen to the voices of people affected by smoking, so that health campaigns and support services can be better tailored to the needs, experiences and perceptions of the people affected.ldquoPeople who smoke donrsquot want to be told what to do, but they donrsquot want the harm and costs that come with smoking either.ldquoBy understanding each other and working together, health and anti-poverty groups will be better placed to learn what really works.A report by the two organisations makes a series of recommendations, including doing more than ldquojust calling on people to stop smoking by supporting them to find alternative coping strategies.Further recommendations are for more positive messages encouraging smokers to quit, with the ldquoemphasis on supporting people rather than on taking something away.The organisations want strategies to tackle smoking and poverty and for better collaboration between health and anti-poverty groups.Poverty Alliance director Peter Kelly added: ldquoPeople living in poverty face pressures that restricts choices and leaves them feeling little sense of control.ldquoWhilst a minority of people living in places affected by poverty actually smoke, the health and financial impacts fall disproportionately on them.ldquoThere is a need to recognise that smoking is a burden on people living in poverty, not a support ndash but in responding to that we need to understand the context in which people are living, and listen to the voices of people living in poverty talking of the valid needs and wishes they are looking to address.

title: uk-decision-to-stay-in-eu-would-be-respected-says-hungarian-minister
story: Szabolcs Takacs visited Britain this week to provide Hungarians with clarity over their status in Britain post-Brexit.The UK was due to depart the EU on March  but MPs on Thursday voted to delay the date of exit.Just had a candid meeting w  Ben Macpherson, Minister for Europe and Migration of the Scottish Govt on #Brexit, the rights of Hungarians in Scotland and #migration. HU appreciates the SCOGOVrsquos support to the HU expat community. Full respect to Scottish identity and traditions. pic eNSWwXBmdash Szabolcs TakaacutecsMarch , A number of MPs and campaigners have called for another vote on EU membership, with the option to remain on the ballot paper.Mr Takacs told the Press Association on Friday: ldquoAs we speak today, I donrsquot see a high probability of a new referendum but what is not a probability today might be a possibility tomorrow.ldquoIf this is the majority opinion, then we will accept it and we will respect it.ldquoWe were not very happy with the result because we enjoyed our partnership with the UK inside the European Union as a full member of the European Union.ldquoBritish politics in general very much respects constitutional identities, traditions, parliamentarianism, the role of national parliaments in decision-making ndash also at the European level ndash and this has been very dear to our hearts.ldquoThatrsquos why for us a country is leaving which is close to us in European policy issues, so in case there is a reverse procedure Hungary will look at it in a constructive manner.Mr Takacs was speaking at the Hungarian Consulate in Edinburgh, which opened in December.He said it was important to give clarity to Hungarians living in the UK and suggested that even in the event of a disorderly Brexit their rights would still be protected.ldquoI think we can say that the acquired rights of the European Union citizens, including Hungarians, were guaranteed at a very early stage of the Brexit negotiations and itrsquos rightly so, he said.ldquoWe have to make sure that their le will not suffer any negative consequences just because there was a democratic decision on the referendum on Brexit.ldquoEventhere is a disorderly withdrawal, a scenario we wouldnrsquot like to see in Hungary, there are unilateral political statements by high level representatives of the UK Government, including the Prime Minister, that they will anyway guarantee the acquired rights of those who are already here and who come and stay in the UK before the check-out date.Mr Takacs added he believes Hungary and Scotland would continue to have close ties when the UK departs the EU.He said: ldquoWe see a lot of potential economically in the Hungarian-Scottish cooperation in future.ldquoCulturally, we very much respect and value your traditions, your culture hellipldquoI believe that Scotland and the Scottish people, the vast majority of them voted for remain, certainly have a high ambition to stay close to the European Union and the member states, including Hungary.

title: cameras-can-be-used-in-r-kelly-case-hearings-judge-rules
story: The Grammy-winning singer did not attend the brief hearing in Chicagorsquos Cook County Circuit Court, but his lawyer took a similar position to the lawyer for Empire actor Jussie Smollett earlier this week and welcomed cameras in the courtroom.ldquoMr Kelly wants this to be an open and transparent process, said lawyer Steve Greenberg.ldquoSo far there have been rumours, there have been allegations hellip but with cameras in the courtroom, everyone will see what really happens.The judge in Smollettrsquos case, who also sits on the Cook County Circuit Court, has not decided yet whether to allow cameras during the actorrsquos trial on charges accusing him of lying to the police about being the victim of a racist and homophobic attack.With neither side objecting to them, though, it is almost certain that the judge will allow them.As for Kellyrsquos case, Associate Judge Lawrence Flood said cameras will be allowed going forward, beginning with the next hearing on March .He also said two of Kellyrsquos accusers have already indicated that they do not want to be photographed, filmed, or have their voices recorded in court.Kelly, , has pleaded not guilty to  counts of aggravated sexual abuse pertaining to four women, including three who were minors at the time the abuse allegedly occurred.The abuse in question is alleged to have occurred over roughly a decade, starting in the late s.The Kelly and Smollett cases have helped turn the hulking courthouse on Chicagorsquos South Side into something of a legal television studio in recent weeks.

title: the-gorbals-mp-who-campaigned-against-the-greatest-slum-menace-i-have-ever-known
story: INTO the church they all crowded: a large number of MPs, Glasgows Lord Provost, the Scottish Secretary of State and his immediate predecessor. Donald Dewar, then the MP for Aberdeen South, took his seat, close to Teddy Taylor, the MP for Glasgow Cathcart.The woman they had come to remember at this requiem mass on Monday, June , , lived just  yards from the Immaculate Heart of Mary Church in Balornock. Her name was Alice Cullen, the first Roman Catholic woman to enter the House of Commons. She was the MP for the Gorbals, and her death occurred  years ago this May.Archbishop James Donald Scanlan told the congregation that Mrs Cullen was "a woman, the likes of whom Glasgow will never see again." He declared that the presence of the Secretary of State "and all the other dignitaries ... is an indication of the high esteem in which she was held by all." To her grandchildren, and all children ndash Mrs Cullen, who was twice married, had three daughters ndash the archbishop urged them to follow the example she had set in devoting so much of her le to serving the community.Alice Cullen might not warrant a mention in, say, the Oxford Companion to Twentieth Century British Politics, or in many political memoirs of the era, but she has a full entry in the first volume of Honourable Ladies: Portraits of Women MPs. Journalist Sarah Mackinlay notes at the outset that Cullens political career was dedicated to improving living standards of the Gorbals people ndash "especially the woefully inadequate housing in which many lived. The Gorbals was notorious as one of the most deprived parts of the UK, home to Britains worst slums."Cullens by-election victory in September  may have owed something to an intervention by the then Prime Minister, Clement Attlee, who urged voters not to be distracted by the "red herrings" of the Communist and Conservative Unionist candidates.When Cullen made her maiden speech in the Commons in December , she took Gorbals housing as her subject. "EvenI were a great orator," she said at one point, "it would be quite impossible for me adequately to describe the slum conditions of my constituency." Nevertheless, she gave a persuasive picture of local housing conditions. "There are many families living in dilapidated, tumble-down, rat-infested buildings," she declared. "The latest statistics show that slightly over , families live in one-apartment houses. Nearly , families live in two-apartment housesNo constituency in Glasgow was worse than the Gorbals, she added. To her, the apartments were mere "dens." She appealed to the Scots secretary, "from the bottom of my heart" for him, together with the local authorities, to make a survey of the Gorbals "with a view to finding a site on which a block of flats might be erected. I have no doubt that such a site could be found for this purpose. I ask him to make a start in the Gorbals, which is the greatest slum menace that I have ever known."Due to her tireless efforts in Parliament over the decades, Sarah Mackinlay writes, "more than  acres of slums were demolished and, by the s, were replaced with modern housing and flats."In all, Cullen fought and won no fewer than seven general elections, proof of the high regard in which her voters held her.In November  she said she would stand down at the next election. Her last recorded question in the Commons occurred on March , , on the subject of the jubilee year of the Forestry Commission.Her death at the age of  made the front page of the Glasgow Herald on May , . The article said she had been recently been taken ill while ing to Glasgow from Westminster and had appeared to make a good recovery in hospital. A local Gorbals councillor said: "Gorbals has lost a great friend. Many, many people in the constituency owe a great deal to Mrs Cullen."Alice Cullen was the maternal grandmother of Elizabeth Cairns, who lives today in Bishopbriggs.passed away.She was very young when Cullen died ndash her own mother died later that same year ndash but she nevertheless has many fond memories of her.She has photographs and home cine-films of Alice Cullen with her family. Theres a picture of wedding, the guests apparently including Bessie Braddock, the campaigning Labour MP. Theres a photograph of Cullen with the Queen at a ceremony in the Gorbals. Somewhere there is a CD recording of that  maiden speech, and, possibly, even a black-edged postcard from Jacqueline Kennedy in response to a letter from Cullen, in which she expressed her condolences on the death of her husband, John F Kennedy, in Dallas in .And, intriguingly, there are some of the MPs prized possessions. There is a copy of Attlees  autobiography, As It Happened, the flyleaf of which bears the signatures not only of Attlee but also of other leading figures in the Labour Party: Hugh Gaitskell, party leader Harold Wilson, Prime Minister between  to  and  to  Herbert Morrison, whose many posts included Foreign Secretary and Home Secretary and Jim Callaghan, the partys last Prime Minister before Tony Blair took office in .Theres also a teapot, inscribed "To Alice, from her Women Colleagues in the House of Commons with warmest good wishes." It is dated December , . Theres a Christmas card from Harold and Mary Wilson, too.Lord Snowden, no less, once took a photograph of a group of a dozen prominent female MPs. Dated sometime in , it shows Cullen alongside other notables: Bessie Braddock, Judith Hart, MargaretHerbison and Barbara Castle."My mother died of pancreatic cancer in December ," says Elizabeth. "She was in terrible pain but she apparently gave a eulogy for Alice at the Immaculate Heart despite being in such agony."I have very vivid memories of my grandmother. She used to come from Parliament and sneak up to see me, and waken me. She would kid on that she was going upstairs for the bathroom. Shed come in and ask me what Id learned at nursery. We were always giggling and laughing."I remember all the family parties where everybody, of course, is smoking in a tiny room."Alice really was the most generous person. You couldnt say you liked something, like thats a nice brooch, or watch and when you got home youd find it in your bag. Thats the type of person she was."She had no interest in material things. She wouldnt covet things or hold onto them. My mum said it got to the point where nobody would ever say such-and-such a thing was nice, because she would just give it to them."Alice had two sisters, Sarah and Annie, who both moved to England, leaving Alice behind in Glasgow. Elizabeth remembers growing up in a political family. One of Alices sisters once voted for Margaret Thatcher, "because she thought it was quite nice for a woman to get in, and that caused an absolute war in the house."Alice, she adds, had a "real moral conscience. She would have been turning in her grave at the thought of what happened with MPs and their expenses. She was a person of a high moral code, and I think thats our family as well."I remember that she was full of fun. Shes been described as a foreboding figure but that wasnt my experience of her at all. She didnt allow children to behave badly or in a spoiled way. She would correct you with a look."She took a genuine interest in handicapped childrens welfare, and family poverty and health issues and nurses rights. She also spoke up forcefully on things like the crisis in care for the elderly. All of these subjects are sadly still relevant today to too many people.She would been out in George Square in Glasgow, doing her things with all the other people campaigning on things like equal pay. A lot of the things she was interested in and spoke up for are still relevant today, and that is sad. But it proves how far ahead of her time my grandmother was."Alice Cullens maiden speech, House of Commons, December , :"I am glad to be given the opportunity of making my maiden speech on housing, a subject of paramount interest to the people whom I have the honour to represent. I feel sure that I shall be given the same courteous and favourable hearing as is usually given to hon. Members when they are making their maiden speeches. I want to confine my arguments to the constituency which I represent. The people of Gorbals are, no doubt, known to hon. Members of this House through the play "The Gorbals Story." The Gorbals people are hard-working, decent citizens, but at the present time they are depressed and disheartened because of the conditions in which they are living. There are many families living in dilapidated, tumble-down, rat-infested buildings."I should like to give some figures which will demonstrate the appalling lack of proper housing accommodation. The latest statistics show that slightly over , families live in one-apartment houses. Nearly , families live in two-apartment houses. For those who have never experienced living in such conditions, it is dficult to imagine the tragedy and the misery of living, eating and sleeping all in the one apartment, especially when the family consists of anything up to eight members, while sometimes in two-apartment houses it is as high as  members. I am sorry to say that amongst these families are many young people in their teens suffering from tuberculosis."There are also in my constituency , houses of one or two apartments which have been scheduled as unfit for human habitation and are still occupied yet because of the shocking neglect of the housing needs of the people of my area, they must continue to be occupied. EvenI were a great orator, it would be quite impossible for me adequately to describe the slum conditions of my constituency. Thousands of young men from Gorbals answered the call in the - war, and their sons in the - war did likewise. They fought for a better way of le, for decent homes in which to rear their families and for a certain amount of home le, of which they are now deprived. They have waited in vain for that result. It is true to say that  families from the Gorbals have been housed, but the tragedy of that is that when these families were transferred to new houses, instead of the tumble-down shacks being demolished they were allowed to be reoccupied."That is how conditions are in my area. I do not blame the Government. Like my hon. Friend who has already spoken, I think the Government have done a great job of work in regard to housing during the last few years, but I feel that many working people in my own constituency have been neglected for nearly  years. When materials and labour were both plentul and cheap, the Government of that day did not think fit to start to remedy the slums and do something for the people living in them, and in particular for the Gorbals constituency, which is, I maintain, the worst in the whole city of Glasgow."My appeal to the Secretary of State for Scotland, from the bottom of my heart, is that he should, in conjunction with the local authorities, make a survey of the Gorbals with a view to finding a site on which a block of flats might be erected. I have no doubt that such a site could be found for this purpose. I ask him to make a start in the Gorbals, which is the greatest slum menace that I have ever known."I was elected to this House on th September and I took my seat on th October. During the first fortnight that I was here, the Press made vicious attacks upon me because I had not spoken in this House about the housing conditions of my people, and especially Mr. Cummings of the News Chronicle, who seemed to think that had I got up in this House and thrown a fit of hysteria, some fairy would have waved a wand and all would have been well in the Gorbals. That does not happen. I appeal to the Joint Under-Secretary of State to do his best to make the survey for which I have asked. We are coming near to Christmas thousands of my people have still to spend Christmas in their dens. The only way I can express myself is by calling their apartments dens. I trust that, in this holy season of Christmas, the season of good will towards men, my appeal will be successful and that by next year, quite a large number of my folk will be able to spend Christmas in much brighter and happier homes."

title: bbc-alba-give-us-same-chance-to-shine-as-new-channel
story: Bosses at MG Alba, which operates BBC Alba in partnership with the BBC, said it must be offered the ldquosame opportunity to shine as the new BBC Scotland channel, which launched last month.It Scotland on an outstanding launch and we continue to wish them well as the channel comes to le in the months ahead.ldquoHowever, the launch of BBC Scotland has also served to shine a light on two title: aberdeenshire council seeking government help over private water supplies
story: Aberdeenshire Council is to write to the Scottish Environment Minister to seek urgent help in getting more North-east homes with private water supplies connected to the mains network.Having helped some  homes which suffered serious water shortages last year, the local authority said it was mindful that  may not be a “one-off event”.Last year’s dry weather, reported officers, was “unprecedented” in terms of the extent of problems for private water supplies.The £, the council spent on providing intermediate bulk containers and bottled water for those in need, is currently being reclaimed from the Scottish Government.And latest surveys indicate that although no properties are currently being assisted by the council, water table levels remain at levels “much lower” than would be expected at this time of year.Members of the council’s Infrastructure Services Committee unanimously agreed that chair Peter Argyle write to Roseanna Cunningham seeking both the assistance of the Scottish Government and Scottish Water to mitigate against future shortages.They heard that Aberdeenshire has more than , properties – both domestic and non-domestic – which rely on private water supplies – the largest number of any local authority area in Scotland.While the upkeep of private water supplies is the responsibility of the property owner or landowner, supplies are vulnerable to fluctuations in quality and quantity, and are often not adequately maintained.In his letter to Ms Cunningham, Councillor Argyle states: “The public supply has many advantages over private water supplies and the overall aim should be to see as many properties as possible connected to the mains network.“The mains network should be extended to enable connections to be made, thereby reducing the number of properties on private supplies.“While it is recognised that it will not be possible to connect all properties to the public supply there are particular clusters of properties where it would be possible to do so.”The council also wants to see property owners being better educated in terms of water usage and a simplication of Scottish Water’s process forthose wishing to connect to the title: busy north east road to close for repairs
story: The A Ellon South Roundabout is set to benefit from #, worth of resurfacing improvements taking place next week.The resurfacing improvements will address defects in the road surface of the roundabout as well as a section of the A just over m long to the north of the roundabout, creating a smoother and safer journey for motorists.The overnight surfacing works are scheduled to start Monday  March and will take seven nights to complete. The project will take place between .pm and .am each night with improvements expected to be completed by .am on Wednesday  March. No works are programmed for Saturday or Sunday nights.To ensure the safety of road workers as well as motorists, an overnight road closure will be in place on the A each night. For traffic travelling north, a ersion route will be in place via the old Athrough Foveran, onto the B, along the B and onto the A through Ellon where motorists will then re-join the A. All motorists travelling southbound will be erted via the A, B, B and along the old Athrough Foveran, where they will re-join the A. The ersion in place overnight will add around  miles or  minutes onto road user’s journeys.All traffic management will be removed from the carriageway during the daytime.Consultation has taken place with local residents and the local authority in advance of the resurfacing to make them aware of the traffic management arrangements and to minimise any inconvenience.Commenting on the improvements, Andy Thompson, BEAR Scotland’s North East Representative, said: “This £, project has been designed to improve the general condition and safety of the Ellon South Roundabout for motorists.“The traffic management is essential to ensure the safety of road workers and motorists during the project. We’ve taken steps to minimise disruption for road users as much as possible during the improvements, including carrying out the works overnight and avoiding working Saturday and Sunday nights.“We thank motorists for their patience in advance while our teams carry out these works on the A. We encourage road users to plan their journeys in advance by checking the Traffic Scotland website for up to date traffic information and allow some extra time to reach their destination.”Real-time journey planning information can be obtained by visiting www.trafficscotland.org or twitter @ trafficscotland.Materials removed from the existing carriageway will be recycled using SEPA approved methods.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.fraserburghherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Brew Toon is one of six local businesses to be shorlisted."
